segments.text: An explanation is acceptable, but the truth of the matter is I drank beer with my friend about two hours when I got to the airport last night.
Suffering agony and pain this morning.
No, thank you.
Just iced tea would be fine.
There's presently a
A developing controversy in North Carolina and the other northeastern states on this potential evulsion has to do with pollution of the Atlantic coast.
What role do you think scientists ought to play, academicians and scientists like yourself, in offering advice, opposition to, support for this environmental concern?
Well, I think we are the people that should give the advice.

When I say we, I mean environmental scientists because that's what I became after I came down here, but a lot of this horror that people express is based on a lack of knowledge and I don't think people can just sit at a desk at a university campus and come up with a whole answer.
For example, Savannah a couple years ago, one of the companies that's been dumping sulfuric acid in the Savannah River,
was ordered to stop doing that, so they decided to dump it in the ocean the way national lead does off the coast of New Jersey.

And right away the sports fishermen in North Carolina put up a big clamor that they're going to destroy the Gulf Stream because this sulfuric acid is going to be carried to the coast of North Carolina.
And the people in the
Division of Fisheries, whatever it's called in Raleigh, got all worked up over this.

Well, I sat down and did a little chemical oceanography with the numbers and showed that every day the Gulf Stream carries past North Carolina about 20,000 times as much sulfuric acid as what they were proposing to dump in and off Georgia.
And also equally greater amounts of the trace metals that were going in with it that people were concerned with.
This is a desk study, which is fun to do.
But on the other hand, off New Jersey, where they've been dumping this now for 20 years, the fishing is actually a little better than it used to be.
The sports fishermen actually go out to look for the acid ground as a place to fish, because there's enough iron oxide on the bottom, so the character of the bottom has changed.
And apparently, this attracts the kind of fish they're chasing.
So here's something based on an actual observation of what's been going on for 20 years.
And yet the people of North Carolina didn't have any knowledge of this and immediately set up a big clamor against it.
And this happens over and over again.
This dumping of sewage sludge off of New York City, for example.
You talk about the Dead Sea there.
That's not so.
I've looked at cores that the Army engineers had taken off New York Bight in this area.
And you can't see any organic matter in the cores.
It's just good gray gravel with pieces of brick in it.
The organic matter is being removed very rapidly.
So again, these assertions about polluting the ocean are based on a lack of knowledge and lack of observation.
Did you become irritated when a man like Jacques Cousteau says, for example, that the sea is dying?
No, because I admire Cousteau very much as an engineer and as an entrepreneur of television movies, but he's not qualified to
speak about what he sees dying because he's never made a measurement of productivity in his life.
He really doesn't know what that means.
So it's a statement that doesn't carry any weight with me.
Do you think that environmental publicists, to coin a word, are good for or bad for oceanography?
That is, that a man like Cousteau, for example, or half a dozen others I can think of, have acquired a great amount of publicity for the oceans.
Is this essentially a good thing?
I don't think it hurts.
It's strange.
When I was small and told people I was going to be an oceanographer, they'd say, oh, do you know William Beebe?
And then later on, when I said I was an oceanographer, they would say, oh, do you know Rachel Carson?
And now they say, do you know Jacques Cousteau?
So it always takes somebody like that to attract public interest to the field.
And I don't see how this hurts.
No.
In terms of public interest to the field,
quality of oceanographic education in the United States, having been involved in at least three different types of institutions and having also taught?
What do you think?
Is it capable, not capable?
I think there's variation.
I think that the best schools are considerably better than the worst schools.
There's a great gradient.
And if I were to hire a young man with a recent PhD in oceanography, I would
consider carefully the school he got it from as one of the main criteria in deciding whether to hire him.
Are Scripps and Woods Hole still the premier schools in oceanography at this time?
I don't think Woods Hole is much of a school yet.
They just recently got into the school business.
But Scripps certainly, well, I have to say that because I came from there.
Well, the whole point, the point is, or the question I'm trying to ask, is that it's been almost impossible, for example,
in my profession, history, to take a school and make it a first-ranked school.
My degree's from the University of Texas.
It's a good second-ranked school.
That's fine.
You know, it's about as good in history as North Carolina, possibly not quite so, a little better than Tulane, not quite as good as the University of Michigan, and a mile away from Harvard and Yale.
It's the same thing true in oceanography.
Can you make an oceanographic institution a first-rate school?
Well, I think some of those that have started pretty much from scratch
have done very well.
The Johns Hopkins operation, I think, was first right from the very beginning.
Miami, I'd say, never has quite gotten off the ground.
Now, this leads to another question about academic education.
Originally, the concept of oceanography was to bring together people from a vast number of scientific disciplines
excuse me, attach them to one place, and that was the School of Oceanography.
Really, their only collective academic interest was the oceans, right?
And each one put an input into the discipline itself.
So there's no such thing, in effect, as oceanography.
Let me explain it this way.
However, lately oceanography has become, once more, more divided.
That is, chemical oceanographers talk to chemical oceanographers.
Is this the way you perceive
I've seen it develop another way.

We've gone from oceanography to marine science, and oceanography is a study of the ocean and its contents, but marine science is everything that you have to do from a ship, and this includes marine meteorology, which not many places do, but it also includes all this sort of stuff that Lamont
Doherty does, and all this, and this deep-sea drilling project of NSF, which doesn't pay any attention to the ocean.
To them, the ocean is a damn nuisance.
They wish somebody would pull the plug out, let the water out, and then they could walk around instead of having to go out on the ship.
So that

There has been a change then from the point of view of studying the ocean as a system to studying the Earth's crust under the ocean, but still call this oceanography and get the oceanographic support for it, which has in the past distressed me a little bit.
For example, when Lamont went into the IGY, the IGY was set up to do synoptic observations.
How do you do synoptic
geologic studies of the ocean floor.
There's no particular need to do them one year as compared with another year.
And yet they got a lot of funding during the IGY for carrying on just what they'd always been doing.
There are glamour disciplines in oceanography, if I may try it this way.
For example, everybody wants to be, in effect, a nuclear physicist in the 1950s.
In oceanography presently,
some parts of it are in eclipse, that is physical oceanography and as a matter of fact marine oceanography in the sense of marine biology.
What do you think will be the glamour fields for oceanography in the future?
Well, I think that the big thrust in the future has to come from resource exploitation and this is fisheries and
and waste disposal.
In other words, studying the effects of man-made pollution on the ocean.
Okay, so you see oceanography turning into a type of environmental studies?
Yeah.
People used to ask me,
Whenever I said I was an oceanographer, by the way, in the middle of the 60s, what about getting fresh water from the sea?
I said, that's not an oceanographic problem.
We've solved the problem.
We provide the seawater.
No one is an engineering problem.
What sort of technological breakthroughs do you think occurred during your experience with oceanography that changed the nature of oceanography?
Well, one of the greatest things was the development of the salinometer so that you no longer had to determine chlorinity by titration.
and the appalling amount of ignorance has resulted from that.

Now people, you know, they're no longer reading a burette, they're reading a meter and they're reading it to more figures and publishing these figures and it was kind of revealing during the IGY when two different groups ran selenometers on the same samples and they published them side by side and the results were appallingly unbearable.
Do you think that it's been suggested that the great age of exploration has ended, in terms of oceanography, and that now may be a period of computation?
Well, we're in the great age of exploration as regards to seafloor with the deep-sea drilling project.
We have by no means wiped that up yet.
There's a lot more going on.
And of course, the breakthrough on development
plate tectonics and the, finally people are willing to admit that there's such a thing as continental drift.
That occurred in the early 1960s and that was another great breakthrough.
I'll tell you a little anecdote about that.
A guy named Mason out at Scripps, an Englishman, wanted to do

just a bunch of routine magnetometer surveys of the ocean, and Scripps couldn't give him the ship time, but he found out that the Coast Survey was commissioning a ship, I think it was called the Pioneer, and that the time was being paid for by the Navy, so he cut together with Roger Revell to see if he couldn't have his magnetometer towed by this Coast and Genetic Survey vessel, and Roger got a hold of me, and I went on into our
I dragged her fur and got down on my knees and said, let's put this in the operation plan for the pioneer to tow this magnetometer.
And the captain said, yes, but the first time this interferes with the other vital things, they'll have orders to cut it away.
And I said, well, that's all right.
We'll put that in the orders.
And of course, these guys in the co-survey are too smart to cut away a magnetometer.
They'd hold it in whenever there was trouble.
And they produced the detailed bathymetry and the detailed magnetic data that convinced

people that this was a good way to go to keep continuing these studies and this led to the work of mine and so on on the fractionation, fracture of the sea floor along the mid-ocean ridges and led to this tremendous breakthrough in the understanding of plate tectonics and so I take a little bit of credit for being one link in the chain that they got this thing underway.
Or does it strike you that in science many things like this seem almost accidental?
Sure.
Which is, it seems as if your discipline is swinging away from the idea of basic research and more and more specific research.
Do you think these accidental discoveries will begin to diminish when this occurs?
No, no.
These things keep turning up.
They discovered the equatorial undercurrent by fishing for

whatever they were fishing for and finding that the fishing lines were trailing in strange ways and they developed the New England swordfish fishery on the basis of going out just to, Frank Mather wanted to catch a few fish and borrowed this long line gear from the Bureau of Commercial Fisheries and the man broke a leg so they left the gear overnight, landed the man to
sent to the hospital, went back and picked it up and found that it was loaded with, with swordfish.
The way to catch swordfish was to set long lines for them overnight.

That led to the big swordfish industry in New England and that in turn was killed when some guy, some graduate student invented a way of determining mercury with ten times more precision than they had in the past and he found that there was a hell of a lot of mercury in swordfish.
An accidental discovery one way, an accidental discovery the other way.
What about the computer?
What's it going to do to your discipline?
Well, certainly the use of a computer is a very expeditious way to handle large bodies of data.
I think Walter Munk was one of the first guys to apply the computer to solving problems of physical oceanography.
It's certainly simplified his analysis of wave and tide observations.

someday every oceanographic observation that's ever been taken will be on a computer and you can interrogate the computer and ask how much has the climate changed in the last ten years in terms of temperatures at a given point.
I don't think we're there yet.
It's tremendously expensive, of course, but it's just the way to go.
You seem to regret that people don't go to sea that much anymore in terms of oceanographic research or that the direction may be in
maybe going that way.
So many guys get seasick and then spend the rest of their career trying to design a buoy system so that they don't have to go out in person.
On the other hand, you have all these scuba guys who think that the only way to find out anything is to go down themselves in scuba, which is alright.
You can find out a limited amount of things in certain areas, but I don't think scuba is the answer.
I don't think little submarines are the answer either.
I think all these things contribute, but I think surface ships
and Nansen bottles are going to be with us for a long, long time to come.
Well, my next question, as a matter of fact, was what about undersea gear?
Have these, has undersea gear's technological breakthrough changed the nature of oceanography?
I don't think so.
Look at the drift of the Ben Franklin, for example.
This was given a vast amount of publicity by Grumman as a great breakthrough.
End of the trip, but...
They had virtually nothing to show for it, and they gave the thing away.
It cost them $4 million, and they gave it away for $25,000.
So you think that at least in the way you perceive the future, guys will still go to the sea in ships and still will do that manual labor and drag those cables and... Lower enantiobottles on a wire.
Nobody had us figure out how to do chemistry in deep water except by lowering an enantiobottle on a wire.
Now, finally, if you had to sum up what you assumed were your accomplishments...
in a long career of oceanography, what would you cite for yourself?

Well, I helped build up the Division of Oceanography at the Hydrographic Office into a fairly competent organization with people who could react quickly to solve the Navy's immediate requirements in oceanographic information.
In NSF, I launched a few ships and built a few buildings that are, I think, still serving.
The buildings, at least, are serving their purpose.
I think most of the ships now have been superseded.
And that's about all.
It's your time now.
What would you like to say about oceanography, to be remembered, that I didn't ask you?
Well, I always like to bring up Henry B. Bigelow.
I think he's one of the most neglected figures in the history of American oceanography.
When I was last with the government, I tried hard to get him one of the President's Science Medals before he died, and I was unsuccessful.
One year, it was because the guy in the Department of Interior, who could have been most instrumental in pushing this, wanted to get the medal himself.
And I did get him the Compass Award from the publishers of Undersea Technology in one year.
Unfortunately, by that time he was too old and feeble to accept the award in person, and Qualify had to appear for him.
But Henry Bigelow certainly is the father of American oceanography, and he's one of the figures that has been most neglected.
Who struck you in oceanography, whom you remember beside Bigelow with fondness?
Oh, I've got all kinds of friends.
Tommy Thompson at University of Washington was a wonderful guy.
He was a real seagoing chemist.
The guy I worked for at Scripps, Muhlberg, was a great guy in his way.
F.G. Walton Smith at the University of Miami is a wonderful character.
He's been a real entrepreneur in directing interest to the Florida area.
Then there was a whole bunch of people who came out of Scripps at the end of the war, who now fill high positions around ocean and gravity institutions.
Art Maxwell at ONR.
Dale Leeper was at Texas, now is at Monterey.
Wayne Burt was at Oregon where he really built that institution up from nothing in a remarkably short time.
Gene Lafond is a character I've been associated with and I'm tremendously proud to have known because Gene had done a lot of tremendous things in his day.
Now,
Just a couple of things while I've got the tape recorder running.
Why was there opposition to Revelle coming back to head scripts?
The opposition that he maintains came from Shepard and from...
The fish man.
The fish man, right.
Yeah.
Well, his name would come to me if I... Yeah, I'll think of it in a minute.
Carl Hubs.
Carl Hubs, right.
Well, people have their own personal ambitions and people have their, have their, also their ideas about how the, how the organization should be structured.
Many departments at universities like to have a week
department head.
They'll pick some fairly junior associate professor and put him in there for five years to handle the paperwork and to do what they tell him to do.
The senior professors get together, they have their own caucus and they arrive at the decision and then they tell the department head what to tell the dean.
Of course, you can't imagine Roger Revelle working that way.
Roger is a strong man wherever he is and
So naturally, the people who prefer this other kind of organization would not be happy about that.
I can remember Roger's predecessor at Charter Scripps, Carl Eckert, telling me that
two things that really led to his decision to retire as director and just go on being a professor.
Of course, one of the beauties of the academic world is that you can quit a higher job than professor and you always get tenure as a professor.
You can't do this necessarily in the Navy, but he had told one of the
buildings and ground, and I think it was Carl Johnson, to do something.
And Carl said, have you cleared this with Roger?
And Carl said, I realized then that I was just a damn figurehead, that there was no point in my trying to be the director of script.
And secondly, why did Monk not receive clearance?
Was it because of his birthplace?
Yeah.
Monk and Swerder were both foreign born, you see, and I don't think either one was a citizen.
I don't think Swerder was a citizen then.
And in 1940 and 41 we had tremendous security problems.
Swerder told me one time that he had been cleared of all charges except associating with Monk.
And Monk was cleared of all charges except associating with Swerder.
And it was Roger Revelle who finally

who finally straightened that one out and got them clearances and it certainly was to the benefit of the Navy that they did this because a whole lot of guys have been drowned on beaches and nothing for the fact that it's right over the bunker for working for the Navy.
Nothing else I want to know unless you want to add something.
I can't do anything this minute.
Okay.
